title-group.article-title: Oral Lining Mucosa Development Depends on Mesenchymal microRNAs

article-meta.aff: 1Craniofacial Development and Stem Cell Biology, and Biomedical Research Centre, Dental Institute, King’s College London, Guy’s Hospital, London Bridge, London SE1 9RT, UK
2Division of Bio-Prosthodontics, Department of Oral Health Science, Course for Oral Life Science, Niigata University Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Niigata, Japan
3MRC Centre for Developmental Neurobiology, King’s College London, New Hunt’s House, Guy’s Campus, London SE1 1UL, UK

fn.p: authors contributing equally to this work

permissions.copyright-statement: © International & American Associations for Dental Research 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: The oral mucosa plays critical roles in protection, sensation, and secretion and can be classified into masticatory, lining, and specialized mucosa that are known to be functionally, histologically, and clinically distinct. Each type of oral mucosa is believed to develop through discrete molecular mechanisms, which remain unclear. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are 19 to 25nt non-coding small single-stranded RNAs that negatively regulate gene expression by binding target mRNAs. miRNAs are crucial for fine-tuning of molecular mechanisms. To investigate the role of miRNAs in oral mucosa development, we examined mice with mesenchymal (Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl) conditional deletion of Dicer. Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice showed trans-differentiation of lining mucosa into an epithelium with masticatory mucosa/ skin-specific characteristics. Up-regulation of Fgf signaling was found in mutant lining mucosal epithelium that was accompanied by an increase in Fgf7 expression in mutant mesenchyme. Mesenchyme miRNAs thus have an indirect effect on lining mucosal epithelial cell growth/differentiation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The oral mucosa plays critical roles in protection, sensation, and secretion. Changes in the oral mucosa can be symptomatic of local mucosa/skin diseases as well as many systemic diseases. The oral mucosa can be classified into masticatory (attached gingiva and hard palate), lining (cheek, soft palate, lips, and floor of mouth; FM), and specialized (tongue papillae) mucosa, which are all known to be functionally, histologically, and clinically distinct. Masticatory mucosa epithelium is either keratinized or parakeratinized, whereas lining epithelium is not keratinized. In addition to keratinization, other epithelial layers also show significant differences between masticatory and lining mucosa. The epithelial cell layers of the masticatory mucosa are similar to those in the epidermis (consisting of granular, spinous, and basal layers), whereas lining mucosa lacks a granular layer and has a thinner spinous layer (Fig. 1A). In addition to epithelium, lamina propria (mesenchyme) is also distinct in each type of oral mucosa. Mesenchyme of masticatory mucosa is a dense collagenous tissue with few blood vessels, whereas lining mucosa has mesenchymal tissue with sparse elastic fibers and a rich vascular supply. In common with other ectodermal organs such as the tooth, epithelial-mesenchymal interactions are believed to be crucial for oral mucosa development. In the development of oral mucosa, both masticatory and lining mucosa show thin epithelium consisting of 1 or 2 layers until E16, and morphological differences are evident from around E18 between masticatory and lining mucosa. Masticatory mucosa epithelium thickens and starts to keratinize at E18.5, which becomes more obvious after birth. Lining mucosa, however, shows no significant morphological differences between E16 and neonatal stages. Although each type of mucosa is believed to develop through discrete molecular mechanisms, little is currently known about these.

caption.p: Oral mucosa in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice. (A) Schematic diagram of masticatory and lining mucosa. Frontal sections showing mandibles (B, C), FM mucosa (D-I, L-S), and hard palate (arrowheads in J, K). Thickened mandibular epidermis (arrowhead in C). Keratinized layer (arrows in E, G). (F, G) Papanicolaou staining. (L-O) Arrowheads indicating FM mucosa. In situ hybridization of K14 (N, O) and immunohistochemistry for K13 (P, Q) and Filaggrin (R, S). (P-S) Yellow arrowheads indicating positive cells. Red arrowheads indicating boundary between epithelium and mesencyme. Wild-type (B, D, F, H, J, L, N, P, R) and Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/f (C, E, G, I, K, M, O, Q, S) at E18.5 (B-K, N-S) and E16.5 (L, M). Scale bars: 800 µm (B); 80 µm (D-I); 400 µm (N, O); 100 µm (P-S). t, tongue; epi, epithelium; me, mesenchyme; oc, oral cavity.

sec.p: microRNAs (miRNAs) are 19 to 25nt non-coding small single-stranded RNAs that negatively regulate gene expression by binding target to mRNAs. miRNAs bind to target mRNAs to impair their translation and stability. miRNAs are synthesized by a multiple-step process and are transcribed as long primary transcripts that are cleaved by Dicer to produce mature miRNAs. In addition to miRNA biogenesis, Dicer is also required for the generation of siRNA derived from endogenous dsRNA transcripts (Tam et al., 2008; Chong et al., 2010). Dicer thus plays a critical role in the biogenesis of multiple classes of small RNAs. The results of Dicer mutant analysis suggest that miRNAs play important roles in regulating the development of sensory ganglia, sympathetic nerves, eyelid, midbrain, cerebellum, tongue, and cardiovascular structures (Huang et al., 2010; Zehir et al., 2010; Nie et al., 2011). The role of miRNAs in oral mucosa development, however, remains unclear.

To understand the role of miRNAs during craniofacial development, we created conditional knockouts of Dicer in either neural-crest–derived mesenchyme (Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl) or oral epithelium (K14Cre;Dicerfl/fl). The phenotypes of Wnt1Cre deletion include inhibition of tooth development, and these are described elsewhere (Oommen et al., 2012). Here we report that, in the same mice, lining mucosa trans-differentiates into an epithelium with masticatory mucosa/skin-specific characteristics. Mesenchymal signals to the epithelium regulated by miRNAs thus play a critical role in oral mucosa development.

sec.title: Production of Transgenic Mice
sec.p: Transgenic mice were produced as described previously (Appendix). Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice were bred on a CD1 genetic background, which was generated by backcrossing to CD1 mice as described (Oommen et al., 2012).

sec.title: In situ Hybridization
sec.p: In situ hybridization was carried out as described previously (Oommen et al., 2012; Appendix).

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Sections were treated by proteinase K and then incubated with antibody to Ki67 (Vector Labs, Burlingame, CA, USA), phosphorylated Smad1, Smad5, and Smad8 (p-Smad1/5/8; Cell Signaling Technologies, Beverly, MA, USA), phosphorylated ERK (p-ERK; Santa Cruz Biotechnology Inc., Santa Cruz, CA, USA), or phosphorylated Smad2 and Smad3 (p-Smad2/3; Santa Cruz Biotechnology Inc.), followed by species-specific secondary antibodies as described. Tyramide signal amplification system (Perkin-Elmer Life Science, Boston, MA, USA) was used for detection of the p-Smad1/5/8, p-ERK, and p-Smad2/3 antibody.

sec.title: Quantitative-PCR (q-PCR)
sec.p: Total RNA was isolated from E16.5 whole mandibles (except tongue) and E12.5 heads and used for Sybr green Q-PCR (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA, USA) (Appendix).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Neural-crest–derived cells have been shown to be present in many regions of the developing head (Chai et al., 2000; Ito et al., 2003). The majority of mesenchymal cells underlying the masticatory and lining mucosa were LacZ-positive (data not shown) in Wnt1Cre;R26R embryos, indicating that they are derived from the neural crest. We next examined mice with mesenchymal deletion of Dicer (Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl) to investigate the role of mesenchymal miRNAs in oral mucosa development.

Previous studies have reported that Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice have no obvious mandible or maxillae (Huang et al., 2010; Sheehy et al., 2010; Zehir et al., 2010; Nie et al., 2011). We found, however, that mandible and maxillae were present in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice on a CD1 genetic background at E18.5, although they were much smaller than those of wild-type mice (Appendix Fig. 1; Oommen et al., 2012). CD1 background Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice thus provided a source whereby we could investigate the role of mesenchymal miRNAs in oral mucosa development. Lining mucosa is normally very thin in wild-type mice but was significantly thicker in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice (Figs. 1C, 1E). The mesenchyme underlying lining mucosa in the mutants showed no significant differences (Fig. 1I). Of the other 2 types of mucosa, there were no significant changes in masticatory mucosa (Fig. 1K), and the specialized epithelium of the tongue could not be analyzed because of the severe phenotype. Therefore, deletion of mesenchymal miRNAs indirectly affects the development of mucosal epithelium, specifically in the floor of the mouth.

Abnormally thickened epithelium of lining mucosa was evident from around E16, although the extent of thickening was variable between individual Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice examined (Fig. 1M). Histological analysis and Papanicolaou staining indicated that the mutant mucosa in the floor of the mouth had heavily ectopic keratinized layers (Figs. 1E, 1G).

We also examined Keratin(K)14Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice to investigate the role of epithelial miRNAs in oral mucosa development, since K14 is expressed in oral mucosa epithelium from E12.5 (Appendix Fig. 2A). Another ectodermal organ, teeth have previously shown minor defects in mice with epithelial deletion of Dicer, including K14Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice (Cao et al., 2010; Michon et al., 2010; Oommen et al., 2012). K14Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice, however, showed no significant changes in hard palate or FM mucosa, suggesting that epithelial miRNAs do not play a major role in oral mucosa development (Appendix Fig. 2B).

We therefore focused on the mucosal phenotype in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl. We examined K14 expression (marker for basal cells) and immunolocalization of Filaggrin (marker for granular cells) and K13 (marker for spinous cells) to investigate which epithelial layer was increased in thickness in the mutants. K14 expression showed no significant changes in mutants, whereas the K13-positive cell layer was thickened in mutant lining mucosa epithelium (Figs. 1O, 1Q). Ectopic Filaggrin-positive cells were also observed in the epithelium of mutant mice (Fig. 1S). These results suggested that abnormally thickened mutant FM mucosa was caused by a thickened spinous layer and by ectopic keratinized and granular layer formation. All these layers are usually evident in masticatory mucosa and epidermis, indicating that the FM mucosa appears to trans-differentiate into an epithelium with masticatory mucosa/skin-specific characteristics. In contrast, ectopic Filaggrin-positive cells could not be detected in FM mucosa of K14Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice, although these cells were present in the typical pattern in the skin and hard palate (Appendix Fig. 2C; data not shown).

Signaling pathways such as Shh, Tgf, Bmp, and Wnt have been shown to play roles in the development of ectodermal organs, including skin. We therefore examined these signaling pathways in the abnormal lining mucosa formation in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice. Overexpression of ActivinβA has been shown to result in thickening of the epidermis (Munz et al., 1999). To assess the level of Activin signaling activity, we examined the location of phosphorylated Smad2 and Smad3 (p-Smad2/3) using immunofluorescence. The p-Smad2/3- positive cells were not seen in FM mucosa of either wild-type or Dicer mutants at E14.5 or E16.5 at the early stages of epithelial thickening in the floor of the mouth. At E18.5, there was significantly increased staining of pSmad2/3 in the ectopic keratinized layer of the mutant FM mucosa, while only a few positive cells were seen in wild-type mucosa at the same stage (Figs. 2A, 2B). However, no significant increase of ActivinβA expression could be detected in mutant FM mucosa at E16.5 or E18.5 (data not shown).

caption.p: Molecular changes in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice. Immunohistochemistry for p-Smad2/3 (A, B), Ki67 (C-F), p-ERK (G, H, J-N), and DAPI (I), and in situ hybridization of Fgf7 (O, P) in wild-type (A, C, E, G, K, M, O) and Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/f (B, D, F, H-J, L, N, P) mice at E16.5 (C-J, O, P) and E18.5 (A, B, K-N). (A, B, K-N) Mergence with DAPI. (C, D) Arrowheads indicating basal epithelial cells. (E, F) High magnification of C and D. Arrowheads indicating boundary between epithelium and mesenchyme. (I, J) High magnification of H. (G-K, M) Arrowheads indicating basal epithelium. (M, N) High magnification of K and L. (L, N) Arrowheads and arrows indicating p-ERK-positive and -negative cells in epithelium, respectively. (P) Arrowhead indicating Fgf7 expression. t, tongue; oc, oral cavity; me, mesenchyme. Scale bars: 300 µm (A, B); 200 µm (C, D, O, P); 400 µm (G, H); 50 µm (N); 800 µm (L).

sec.p: Increased Wnt signaling has been shown to induce thickened tongue epithelium (Zhao et al., 2009). Significant changes in the target gene and pathway mediator, Axin2, could not be detected in the lining mucosa, although other parts of mandibles showed up-regulated Axin2 expression (data not shown). Altered canonical Wnt signaling is thus unlikely to be a cause of abnormal FM mucosa formation. We also excluded Shh and Bmp from playing a major role in mediating the mutant epithelial phenotype, based on the lack of change in Ptch1 expression (marker for Shh signaling activity) or p-Smad1/5/8-staining (marker for Bmp signaling activity; data not shown).

The thickened epithelium suggested that there might be increased proliferation in the epithelium. Indeed, we found that the number of Ki67-positive cells was increased in the basal layer in mutant FM mucosa at E16.5 [16.95 ± 3.60% (percentage of Ki67-positive cells/total basal cells; means ± SD) in wild-type and 50.01 ± 9.23% in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice] (Figs. 2C-2F). Since Fgf signaling is known to regulate cell proliferation in skin development (Petiot et al., 2003), we next examined p-ERK, which is a readout of the FGF pathway. The number of p-ERK-positive cells was increased in the basal layer of mutant FM mucosa at E16.5, suggesting that Fgf signaling is up-regulated early in the mutant basal cells (Figs. 2H, 2J). However, at E18.5, p-ERK-positive cells were not present in basal layers, whereas they were observed in the mutant spinous layer and ectopic granular layer of FM mucosa (Figs. 2L, 2N). These results suggest that p-ERK-positive cells in the mutant basal layer at E16.5 differentiate into spinous and granular cells by E18.5, whereas new basal cells show no obvious Fgf signaling activity.

Increased Fgf signaling in mutant FM mucosa epithelium raised the possibility that Fgf ligand expression was increased in the mesenchyme as a result of lack of miRNAs. We examined several Fgfs, and of these, Fgf7 expression was found to be up-regulated in mesenchyme facing the epithelium of mutant FM mucosa (Fig. 2P). Q-PCR analysis with RNA extracted from whole mutant and wild-type mandibles at E16.5 also showed increased Fgf7 expression in mutants (Appendix Fig. 3). Since the receptor for Fgf7, Fgfr2, is normally expressed in oral mucosa epithelium, we propose that Fgfr2 mediates the response of the epithelium to increased mesenchymal Fgf7 in the mutant mice (data not shown; Lin et al., 2009). Consistent with this idea, transgenic mice overexpressing Fgf7 have an abnormally thick epidermis similar to that seen on the external surfaces of Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mandibles (Fig. 1C; Guo et al., 1993).

We next mined several databases to search for miRNAs that can target Fgf7 (Appendix Table 1) and then examined published expression data (Euroexpress; http://www.eurexpress.org/ee/) to determine whether any of these miRNAs was expressed in craniofacial mesenchyme. In addition to miRNAs curated from these databases, we also examined the expression of 2 miRs, miR7a and miR203, in our laboratory by in situ hybridization using locked nucleic acid (LNA) probes. LNA technology enhances signal specificity and strength. Expression of miR7a, miR16, miR143, miR150, miR203, miR181a, miR346, miR361, miR370, miR375, miR409-3P, miR433, and miR682 was observed at low levels in both epithelium and mesenchyme of FM mucosa (Figs. 3A, 3B, Appendix Fig. 4; Appendix Table 2). miR141 and miR129-5P are weakly expressed in mesenchyme of FM mucosa, whereas they are strongly expressed in epithelium. miR181b was strongly expressed in mesenchyme of FM mucosa, whereas it was weakly expressed in epithelium. All of these miRNAs should be absent from most mesenchymal cells by the deletion of Dicer (Figs. 3C, 3D) and could lead to increased Fgf7 expression.

caption.p: miRNAs and Dicer in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice. (A-C) In situ hybridization of miR7a (A) and miR203 (B, C) in wild-type (A, B) and Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/f (C) mice at E12.5 (A) and E14.5 (B, C). Scale bars: 400 µm (A-C). t, tongue; me, mesenchyme. (D) Quantification of the relative mRNA amounts of Dicer in heads of Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/f mice at E12.5. (E) Schematic diagram of lining mucosa in wild-type and Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/f mice. Gene expression of ligands including Fgf7 in lining mucosa mesenchyme is repressed by miRNAs in wild-type mice. Loss of miRNAs in mesenchyme leads to increased gene expression, including Fgf7, in mesenchyme that binds to their receptors in epithelium, resulting in thickening of lining mucosa in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In our study, we showed that mesenchymal deletion of miRNAs with Wnt1Cre;Dicer fl/fl indirectly led to thickening and trans-differentiation of lining epithelium. Mesenchymal signals to the epithelium regulated by miRNAs thus play a critical role in FM mucosa development. We investigated in detail the activity of several signaling pathways and found that Fgf and Activin-mediated activity was increased in the mutants. The mesenchymal-epithelial signals in the oral cavity are mirroring those seen elsewhere in the body, such as the dermis-corneal epithelium interactions (Ferraris et al., 2000; Pearton et al., 2005).

Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl embryos showed up-regulation of Fgf7 expression in FM mucosa mesenchyme, increased epithelial cell proliferation, and abnormally thickened epithelium of FM mucosa and epidermis. Mesenchyme-derived Fgf7 is known to act as a mitogen for epithelial cells, and mice overexpressing Fgf7 have been shown to have abnormally thickened epidermis (Rubin et al., 1989; Guo et al., 1993; Finch et al., 1995). Another factor that might have contributed to the thickened epithelium is increased cell survival. The Fgf pathway is known to suppress apoptosis (Powers et al., 2000); therefore, increasing the Fgf pathway by deleting miRNAs might inhibit apoptosis, resulting in thickened epithelium. Likewise, in addition to cell growth, mutant FM mucosa showed abnormal differentiation of epithelial cells. It is conceivable that levels of Fgf7 or other signals regulate oral epithelial cell differentiation. Two such signals might be Igf and Notch, both of which are also known to act as critical mesenchymal signals in skin (Weger and Schlake, 2005; Hu et al., 2010).

Significantly increased numbers of p-Sma2/3-positive cells were observed in the ectopic keratinized layer of mutants at E18.5, although these could not be detected when thickened FM mucosa was in the process of forming. No significant up-regulation of the ligand ActivinβA, however, could be detected in mutants at E18.5; therefore, other ligands, such as Tgfβs, are likely mediating this response. Tgfβs are known to be expressed in skin and can inhibit keratinization (Choi and Fuchs, 1990; Gold et al., 2000). Tgfβ signaling has often been shown to be regulated through negative feedback mechanisms in many organs, and it is thus possible that ectopic keratinized cells induce Tgfβ signaling as a negative feedback loop in mutant FM mucosa (Miyazono, 2000).

The clinical relevance of our study is that altered miRNA expression has been observed in diseases affecting the oral mucosa, including leukoplakia and lichen planus (Danielsson et al., 2012; Nylander et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2012). miRNAs are also expressed in normal adult oral mucosa (Benakanakere et al., 2009; Jevnaker et al., 2011). It is possible that the molecular changes of FM mucosa in Wnt1Cre;Dicerfl/fl mice are similar to those seen in the precancerous condition of lichen planus. Analysis of our data suggests that it is the mesenchymal changes in miRNA expression that are more critical for the progression of the disease.

The oral mucosa is a clinically important tissue, since abnormal oral mucosa is often a symptom not only of mucosa/skin disease but also of many systemic diseases. Understanding the molecular basis of oral mucosa formation may thus help provide insights into the development of new therapeutic strategies for treatment of these diseases.

ack.p: We thank Elaine Fuchs for providing mice, Alasdair Edger for Papanicolaou staining, and Alex Huhn for technical support.

fn.p: The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
